185965204.review:
Si basa sulla soluzione di rompicapi via via più difficili, del tipo che devi recuperare un oggetto custodito dietro una porta costituita da una barriera di energia puntandogli un jammer, ma il jammer si trova dietro un'altra porta che per aprirla ci vuole in puntatore laser a luce blu, ma non puoi usarlo direttamente perché c'è un altro fascio laser a luce rossa che interferisce, allora devi trovare la triangolazione giusta per non far collidere i fasci laser disponendo i ripetitori con angolazioni diverse, il tutto cercando di evitare le trappole esplosive... e così via.
Altre porte, quelle per salire di livello, si aprono incastrando le tessere raccolte in precedenza secondo uno schema geometrico - matematico.
Ricorda molto i test per misurare il QI; facendo tutto da soli, senza andare a guardare le soluzioni su youtube, Il livello A può essere superato velocemente anche da chi ha un QI normale, I livelli successivi B e C richiedono un QI maggiore di 120 oppure grande pazienza e testardaggine.
L'ambientazione è molto bella, il livello A riproduce le rovine di Pompei e del Foro Romano; il livello B le tombe dell'antico Egitto, il C castelli medioevali. Suggestiva la ricostruzione di una cattedrale gotica all'interno della quale echeggia un coro gregoriano.

La trama del gioco è dedicata all'intelligenza artificiale, Il giocatore impersona una IA che è stata creata per  motivi di ricerca al fine di sviluppare l'autocoscienza e il libero arbitrio.
Alla IA viene fatto credere di essere l'anima di un defunto che deve aprirsi la strada verso la vita eterna superando una serie di prove logico - matematiche, guidato dalla voce di Dio che viene dall'alto che lo esorta a continuare per mostrare la sua fede.

Nei terminali sparsi lungo il percorso che il giocatore può consultare, si annida un'altra IA, quella del "bibliotecario", che come un demone tentatore cercherà di mettere in dubbio le convinzioni etiche del giocatore ponendo delle questioni di ordine filosofico - morale  che prevedono risposte scelte da un elenco di risposte multiple. 
Ogni terminale contiene un frammento di informazione, una lettera, una email, un brano di un libro: legende dell'antica Roma, il libro dei morti di Osiride, passi della Bibbia, citazioni di filosofi e pensatori... ma l'archivio dei testi è corrotto, incompleto o illeggibile, e così le informazioni che si rivelano sono vaghe e frammentate. 

SPOILER

Una volta però che sono stati raccolti tutti gli indizi, è possibile farsi un quadro chiaro della situazione: Il programma di addestramento della IA è corrotto e incompleto, e non c'è più nessun essere umano a supervisionare i computer perché sono tutti morti, l'umanità è stata distrutta da un virus letale, il "Norvegese Blu" che si è liberato dal permafrost a seguito del riscaldamento globale.
I programma di addestramento va avanti da solo da chissà quanto tempo, girando su un server alimentato da una centrale idroelettrica che ancora funziona.

Il gioco ha finali multipli: se il giocatore sceglie di attraversare le porte del paradiso al termine delle prove verrà considerato da "Dio" un esperimento fallito, resettato, aggiornato il firmware, cancellata la memoria, e riavviato il programma. In pratica il gioco ricomincia da capo.
Se invece rifiuta di varcare la porta del paradiso, e si perde nel cercare tutte le porte e tutti i bonus, finirà per diventare parte integrante della simulazione, senza più la possibilità di uscirne, promosso al rango di "messaggero di Dio".
Solo chi rifiuta la vita eterna e disubbidisce a "Dio" viene premiato trasferendolo  nell'hardware di un robot fisico, che si sveglierà nel mondo reale, in un mondo post apocalittico con le città in rovina invase dalla vegetazione, completamente solo e libero di fare ciò che vuole.

Interessanti gli spunti filosofici, tesi a sviscerare il tema "è umana una macchina che ragiona come un uomo?" (sarebbe questo in essenza il "principio di Talos"),  ma sono stati toccati solo superficialmente, limitati in pratica allo scambio di battute tra le domande della IA e le risposte del giocatore, che può scegliere solo tra una numero limitato di risposte predefinite.

Peccato. Il tema avrebbe meritato un maggiore approfondimento.

La visione etica della IA tradisce la vocazione woke degli sviluppatori, alla domanda: "cosa vorresti fosse massimizzato tra le persone?" tra le risposte multiple compaiono le solite comunistate tipo "la distribuzione eguale dei beni", ma anche la "La Libertà".
Se però rispondi "la Libertà" il perfido bibliotecario ti dice che la libertà non esiste, perché se un islamico vuole discriminare le donne e tu no, tu non sei libero di trattarle da pari, e lui non è libero di discriminarle. Se scegli la risposta "implementare il massimo della libertà possibile senza ledere quella di nessuno" ti risponde sbuffando che è una bella utopia, ma impossibile da mettere in pratica perché (secondo lui) ci vuole un dittatore che faccia da arbitro.

Altro indizio della cultura woke, leggendo le tra le righe delle email recuperate nei terminali, i programmatori della IA si lamentano di quei "pazzi" che in vista della fine del mondo corrono nei rifugi ammassando viveri e armi. Loro, che si ritengono più saggi, si danno consigli su come lasciare i croccantini nella ciotola per aiutare i loro animali domestici quando i loro padroni si saranno estinti, e pianificano di suicidarsi per andarsene via tutti insieme appassionatamente senza aspettare che sia la malattia a ucciderli (visto mai che guariscano...).

L'impressione che ho ricevuto è che i nerd che hanno sviluppato il gioco sognano un mondo dove l'umanità, che mal sopportano, sia stata finalmente spazzata via, e al suo posto ci sono delle creature a loro immagine e somiglianza: esseri senza carattere e ambizioni, totalmente privi di una vita sessuale, che "vivono" ricaricandosi le pile grazie a elettricità prodotta da fonti rinnovabili.

A parte questo il gioco è molto coinvolgente, la soluzione dei rompicapo richiede capacità logiche deduttive non trascurabili e affatto banali, e la grafica è davvero ben fatta.

185674648.review:
[h1]The [strike]Talon[/strike] Talos Principle...[/h1]
[b][u]The Talos Principle[/u] immerses you in a stunning world filled with puzzles and philosophical musings. Each level is beautifully crafted, and the environments create a sense of grandeur and mystery. The player explores the ruins of ancient civilizations that contrast with high technology, creating a unique atmosphere where the past and the future intertwine.[/b]  

[b][u]The musical score[/u] in the game is superb and complements the atmosphere perfectly. The sounds of nature, melodic compositions, and electronic motifs create a harmonious soundscape that helps players focus on solving puzzles. The music shifts depending on the situation, adding depth and emotional weight to the gameplay.[/b] 

[b][u]One of the hallmarks[/u] of The Talos Principle is its combination of puzzles and philosophical questions about consciousness, free will, and human nature. The player doesn't just solve problems, he is confronted with deep thoughts about his existence. This makes the game not only fun, but also thought-provoking.[/b] 

[b]The Talos Principle [u]is not just a game;[/u] it is an experience that leaves a lasting impression. The combination of stunning graphics, captivating music, and philosophical inquiries makes it one of the best in its genre. I would rate this game a [u]9.5 out of 10.[/u] I highly recommend it to anyone looking for something more than just entertainment![/b]

Comme d'autres l'ont dit, vous êtes lâché dans le monde, et on attend de vous que vous vous débrouilliez tout seul. Il n'y a pas de « tutoriel » sur les objets qui font quoi ou sur la façon dont vous êtes censé résoudre une énigme. Vous vous débrouillez tout seul.

L'une des autres choses que j'aime le plus dans ce jeu, ce sont les petits codes QR qui sont disséminés dans les niveaux et dans le monde. Les anciens « cobayes » laissaient des notes pour les futurs « cobayes ». Vous pouvez pointer votre curseur sur le code QR dans le jeu et il s'affichera, mais j'ai décidé de télécharger un lecteur de code QR sur mon smartphone et je l'ai scanné avec mon appareil photo et il le lit. Je trouve que c'est une touche très agréable.

Dans l'ensemble, il s'agit d'un jeu de puzzle fantastique et magnifique. Si vous êtes un fan de Portal, vous voudrez certainement vous procurer ce jeu. Et n'oubliez pas qu'il fonctionnera sans problème sur la plus minable des plates-formes.

185519894.review:
Incredibly unique game which allows the gameplay to interact naturally with the philosophical narrative, described quite clearly through the terminals found around the game. The game takes simple rules/tools, then lets you teach yourself increasingly complex applications of those rules/tools. As you learn more, you start applying those tools outside the original expectations of those rules, which is just so, so satisfying. 

This is the best puzzle game I've ever played, though I'll admit I have limited experience with the genre. Highly recommend that you take your time during the playthrough, read the terminals, and enjoy both the puzzles and what the game makers are trying to say. While philosophically I think the message of the game is dead-wrong, it is well told and can make you think, at least a little.

185480732.review:
TL;DR:

At it's best, this is a great puzzle game that can be an engaging and fun jumping off point on a journey of wide philosophical exploration. 

At it's worst, this game presents a compelling story that (when left unquestioned) justifies a worldview of western domination and idolization of technology. 

The experience for most is probably somewhere in between. 

Shouts out to the creators, the game is a work of art. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I have mostly great things to say about this game. The ambient landscape is beautiful, the mystery of the story is compelling from beginning to end, and the puzzles are for the most part engaging and fun to play. Many of the puzzles force you to think outside the box in ways that will make you very frustrated before you figure it out, and[u] very [/u]satisfied once you do figure it out. 

Players who like a genuine challenge and players who like story rich gaming alike will enjoy this game. If you love Portal, you will love this game and you'll get a head start in figuring it out (many of the mechanics are familiar). The middle of the game felt like a bit of a slog, but that feeling didn't last too long. Overall, I highly recommend this game!

[b]However[/b], I do have some words of caution for the player. This game is best played with an open, and critical, mind. If you are paying attention to the story, and especially if you are engaging with all of the content like the text files in the archive and the audio files scattered throughout the world, you will be confronted with many deep philosophical inquiries. It's an important and beautiful part of the game! Pay close attention to how it unfolds. 

As you progress through this game, and particularly towards the end, there is a sense of finality to the philosophical statements being made by the characters. Especially with Alexandra Drennan's audio recordings, the way her character is built up in the canon of the game gives her a feeling of great authority when she speaks on these deep questions. I find it really beautiful the way her audio recordings play out, and I enjoyed going on that journey. I also found issue with many of the philosophical statements she made, noticing that there are a lot of assumptions present that are never approached or unpacked meaningfully. 

I appreciated the dialogue with the Serpent (Milton) as a place to have a more choice-based way of exploring the philosophical ideas present, but I quickly realized that my choices weren't affecting the dialogue much and it felt very frustrating. I also felt very limited in those interactions by the dialogue choices I was given, and that made the game less fun in those moments. If you start to be more expansive in your view of consciousness during conversations with Milton, Milton becomes somewhat patronizing, and though Milton acquiesces to what you're saying in the end, Milton does so in a way that makes clear that those ideas are kind of wacky and far-fetched. The more you get in line with Milton's sort of [i] nihilistic materialism[/i], the more legitimate your responses are treated. 

At the end of the day, I can't deny that a large part of my experience is that I just don't agree with a lot of the philosophical ideas that are core to this games narrative. [i]But that is the purpose of philosophy - to question fundamental ideas[/i]. I think it is very important to realize and remember that the philosophical ideas being presented in this game are specific to certain schools of thought - namely, [b]Western Materialism[/b]. Western materialism isn't a neutral philosophy either, let's remember that it formed the basis for the development of theories about race and "social evolution" that justified genocides and hostile takeovers around the world, not to mention the unbridled extraction of natural resources that has put us in the pickle we are in today. This game is a clever and creative way of introducing players to western materialism, and I hope that players can continue their philosophical exploration from there. If you're interested in that, here are some questions you could start with: 

Can you identify the central philosophical questions that the game is dealing with? How would you word them? 

Based on the aesthetics of the different "worlds" within the garden, what histories/places/cultures are informing the ideas in the game? What histories/places/cultures aren't represented, and what might they have to say about the games central philosophical questions? (hint: east asia, south asia, north america, central america, etc.) 

Are there assumptions hidden within the central philosophical questions? Within this game? Within the philosophical traditions they are drawing from? 

When Alexandra Drennan says "civilization", what does she mean by that? What kinds of ideas/structures/forms is she referring to? What can you infer from context, and what could that tell you about this characters background and worldview?

What kinds of things have to be present in the world of this game in order to enable something like the Institute of Applied Neomatics to exist? To enable a project of this scope to be undertaken? What kinds of resources? What may that have looked like within the context of the inferred disaster event that supposedly killed off humanity? In what ways could this project have been controversial in the world of the game at that time? 

Do you think that the project led by Alexandra Drennen at IAN, within the context of the game, was worthwhile? Why or why not?

185433231.review:
[h1][b]Un chef-d'œuvre du jeu d'énigmes[/b][/h1]
[i]The Talos Principle[/i] est un jeu où l'on résout des énigmes situées dans des salles dans différents niveaux. La grande qualité de ce jeu c'est clairement [b]ses énigmes avancées qui sont extrêmement gratifiantes à résoudre[/b]. Chaque élément de puzzle est simple à comprendre et tellement bien exploité.

[h1]Les plus[/h1]
• [b][u]Des énigmes très bien conçues[/u][/b]. Certaines assez corsées surtout si on veut les étoiles.
• [u]Beaucoup d'éléments de jeu différents[/u] avec certains très ingénieux comme le double temporel.
• Bonne ambiance, que ce soit au niveau visuel ou musical.
• [u]Très bonne durée de vie pour le genre[/u]. Faites aussi le DLC, il est excellent et bien retors par moment.
• L'histoire philosophique et le lore en arrière-plan, ça fonctionne très bien pour ce type de jeu.

[h1]Les moins[/h1]
• L'obtention de certaines étoiles nécessitent des interactions entre les salles, parfois c'est trop difficilement trouvable tant c'est tordu.

[b]Vous aimez les énigmes ? Jouez-y ![/b]

185404797.review:
The Talos Principle was the most interesting game I played in 2024. Developed by Croteam from Croatia, it's a first-person philosophical puzzle game with very beautiful graphics, about an AI that needs to achieve consciousness in order to save the legacy of humanity, which was wiped out by a virus. Written by someone with a master's degree in philosophy, it really does a great job of raising relevant philosophical questions, although I completely disagree with the author's position.

In fact, I liked the game so much that I made a Twine version of one of the interactive fictions contained in the Road to Gehenna expansion and created an interactive fiction based on this game, called Anastasis. I joined the TTP community on Reddit, and the reception of my game was good, even though I’m arguing the opposite of what the game does. "I disagree, but I really liked the way you presented your argument," is what they told me, and that’s exactly what I thought about the game as well.

185274089.review:
Проба пера перед настоящим шедевром The Talos Principle 2 с разницей в 9 лет.

У меня есть ряд претензий к первой части, хотя по итогу я все равно рекомендую игру, так как без неё не было бы второй части, мной горячо любимой.

Итак, первая претензия - это неподчинение собственным же правилам во время разгадывания загадок. Персонаж может прыгнуть на метр, а может и на три метра. И заранее спрогнозировать, в голове прикинуть можно ли куда-то забраться не получится. Это очень сильно портит логику загадок, потому что доверять собственным глазам нельзя получается. Для меня это очень раздражающий фактор. Во второй части таких проблем нет. Также порой ты можешь залезть на декорации там, где ты даже не предполагал, что это вообще возможно. А это понимать нужно для решения некоторых загадок.

Где край карты непонятно. Просто иди на ощупь пока тебе Элохим не начнет намекать развернуться. Обыскивать локации на предмет интересностей становится гораздо утомительнее, приходится делать много лишних телодвижений.

Очень разочаровывает пиксель хантинг лучей за полкарты, когда даже на мониторе 4К едва видно красный или синий источник луча.

Некоторые звезды так запрятаны, что в здравом уме никак не разгадать их. Невидимый источник луча и приёмник луча? Запросто! Иди ищи.
А как насчет сфотографировать на свой реальный телефон куаркод, расшифровать двоичный и шестнадцатеричный код, загуглить и зайти на википедию на нужную статью, прочитать её и найти там нужное время, перевести его в римскую 24хчасовую систему и нажать кнопочки, чтобы получить звезду? Кротим, вы грибов объелись или в каком месте такие загадки должны быть очень интересными? Это даже не пасхалка, это блин загадка, которая нужна для одного из финалов игры. Для меня такой подход - это геймдизайнерская катастрофа.

Многие записи в терминалах кажутся лишними и неинформативными. В сравнении со второй частью прям очень посредственный интерес вызывают. Мало информации ЛОРного характера, однако замечу интересны диалоги с помощником и чатики в Геенне.

Музыка в какой-то момент надоедает, раздражает, мешает сосредоточиться. Особенно религиозные песнопения. Но сам композитор Мравунац ко второй части очень вырос и тамошний саундтрек просто Голливудский шедевр!

Очень жду переиздание на движке UE5, обязательно куплю!

Talos Principle tamamiyle bir bulmaca oyunu. Sahip olduğu 5-6 temel mekanik üzerine kurulmuş bir bulmaca odaları temasında bir oyun. Bir odada sadece 1 mekanikle birinde 4 mekanikle oynuyorsunuz. Ama bu düz mantık misali ne kadar çok mekanik o kadar zor gibi bir durum yaratmıyor. Oyunun kendi içerisinde o kadar güzel mikro mekaniklere sahip ki  sanki 20-25 mekanikle oynuyorsun oyunu. Oldukça fazla neredeyse birbirinden tamamen farklı -ileriki aşamalarda minik puzzle tarzının tekrarını görebiliyorsun ama olacak o kadar- 120 puzzle'a sahip bir yapım. Bunlardan bazıları özellikle çok ince düşünce gerektirirken bazıları da "S*ktir bunları çözen de insan" dedirtecek seviyede puzzle'lar. Özellikle oyunda olan birkaç sondan bazılarını yapmak için gerekli olan yıldızları alma yöntemi oyundaki ana mekanik olan odaları tamamiyle silip atıyor tüm harita bazında sizi oldukça aykırı düşünmeye zorluyor. Sonlar demişken oyunun 3-5 farklı sonu var. Ama şimdi düşünüyorsun "Abi bu puzzle oyunu farklı son ne alaka" diye. İşte burada oyunun ikinci ana olayı geliyor. Felsefe. Çok felsefik biri olmadığım ve bu tarz şeylere kafa yoran biri olmadığımdan aşırı giremedim olaylara ama ama düşüncelerinizin sınandığı olaylar oynayanları bekliyor. Fikrimi belirtecek yetkim olmasa da oynayan kişiler bu oyunun felsefesini oldukça etkili bulmuş.

Kısaca vizelerimden sonra bu oyunu oynamak bir tık yanlış yer yanlış zaman durumu yaşatsa da bulmacaların yarattığı o kaliteli zamandan keyif aldım. Öneriyorum. 🥈🅖🅤🅜🅤🅢🥈

“我十分舒服，没有和你一起上船。“

这游戏的文本剧情好像是想表达点什么，但是我是真看不明白。

解谜还是有趣的，但是感觉引导有点一般，一些操作只有靠近之后视觉上的提示，没有设计教学关（或者说由于可以不按顺序玩，特别是一个房间内的关卡没有顺序，导致还没玩到教学关就上强度了），例如：
[list]
[*][spoiler]炸弹头上放方块[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]已经开启的风扇上还可以堆方块[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]可以捡起比自己位置低的东西[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]录像里的方块不能用来垫脚[/spoiler]
[/list]
等等，大部分属于”尝试之前想不到，尝试之后觉得倒也合理”的操作。

其次是一点个人偏好，我不太喜欢录像机这种需要卡 timing 的解谜，特别这录像机还只能回放一次，不仅失败一次要重来挫败感极强，在录制的过程中还要站着不动傻等，体验不太连贯。

但是毕竟老游戏了，也可以理解，打骨折买也很便宜，要什么自行车。

185145201.review:
Ce jeu est une gemme.
Vous pouvez bien sûr compléter toutes les épreuves l'une derrière l'autre et foncer au bout, ce qui fait déjà pas mal de contenu (autour de 150 énigmes en comptant les sigils, [spoiler]étages, étoiles, messagers ...[/spoiler] ). Avec des mécaniques intéressantes qui se combinent de beaucoup de façons, parfois surprenantes.

Mais se plonger dans l'histoire est vraiment un plus. Ça commence, outre la voix d'Elohim, avec les textes à lire, ce qui au premier abord peut sembler un peu sec, mais entre les textes philosophiques, tous les éléments qui vont vous permettre de petit à petit comprendre l'histoire du jeu (contexte, enjeux, événements avant ...), les joutes avec l'IA (encore de la philo mais pas que), les enregistrements d'Alexandra (mes préférés) ... C'est vraiment très bien fichu pour vous faire tout découvrir.

J'ai ouï dire qu'un remaster va sortir. Mais le jeu est déjà très beau.

Je ne regrette qu'une chose : que le système d'évaluation de Steam ne me laisse pas mettre un 10/10, mais seulement un vague oui/non. Je ne comprends pas bien l'intérêt d'un système aussi limité.

Was soll also das Gefasel mit der 11?

Klare Empfehlung.

While I’ve been diving into puzzle games, I thought I would give The Talos Principle a go as I’ve heard nothing but great things. At 5 hours in, I’m done. It’s too slow to build the puzzles up or introduce concepts, and when it does, the introduction can be jarring. The environments are dull, interactivity is limited, and because there’s so many variations of the same puzzle, the satisfaction of reaching a solution waned quickly. 

I understand people like this game because of the philosophical themes and metaplot, and maybe this is because it’s 10 years old and my patience is thin these days, but I’m finding it all pretty wanky and delivered in the driest way possible — via computer / email logs.

So the question to anyone who has played the game through: when does it get good?

Bu yüzden kötü duran modellerden mekan tasarımlardan falan şikayet edecek değilim. Ancak bulmacaların dozunu öyle bir uçurmuşlar ki oyun mu oynuyorum en zor seviye sudoku çözmeye mi çalışıyorum belli değil. Artık bir yerden sonra bulmacalara patlattığım kafalar çok yormaya başlayınca oyunu açmaya korkar hale geldim. Zaten yorgun argın eğlenmek dinlenmek için geçmişim bilgisayarın başına bir de fazladan bu oyuna mesai harcıyorum. 

Yine de bu tarz bir oyun yapmanın ne kadar zor olduğunun farkındayım ve geliştiricileri takdir ediyorum. Bulmaca oyunlarının hitap ettiği kitle küçük olduğu için oyun stüdyoları bu alana pek yanaşmıyor. Bu yüzden ortaya böyle bir iş çıkmışken destek olmak lazım.

184203001.review:
I've only just discovered this game and almost finished the first section "A". So, ten years old, but I think this is a very worthy game to try, especially if you want something to "think" about aside from the puzzles which make up the main game action. By themselves the puzzles are a nice challenge, solvable with some trial and error, so no need to look up cheats. This game will keep me going for many hours to come. No need to rush, no ticking clock. I can play at a fairly casual pace when I need a break from my other games. 

BUT as I progress I've become more engaged in the somewhat vague storyline --- bits of info found in emails, memos and text files.stored on the computer terminals located in each section. It's clever, a mystery. and I'm now quite curious to know more. Am I human? Is this a matrix? Is technology dangerous? Lots to think about as you play. I hope they dared to go deep!

Bom jogo, porém tem uns erros até graves na tradução para o Português.
O pior foi numa frase que inclusive foi dublada, mais ou menos assim:
[i]"O seu destino mente nos jardins do mundo."[/i]
Hein?
Fiquei pensando e lembrei que [b]"lie"[/b] em inglês também significa "jazer, descansar, repousar".
Não vi o original mas imagino que seria algo como: [i]"Your destiny/fate lies in the gardens of the world."[/i]
Por ser dublado dá pra ver que não foi um erro que acabou passando ou um erro de tradução automática.
Um cara leu, falou e gravou.

184009550.review:
Strongly recommended. This is a very, very good game. Similar to Portal (without the humor - this is a more serious story), but most definitely not a copy.

Steam tells me I've played it for 65 hours - sounds about right. I bought it on sale a couple of weeks ago, and have played it through three times in a row to get the different endings - having a really bad memory makes most puzzles seem new even when it's the third time you solve it in ten days or so :-) 

It looks great, with good voice acting and script. I would suggest [i]not[i] learning too much about the game and story before playing it. Let it unfold in the game instead.

A handful of the (many) puzzles are really tricky, but most of the times that I got stuck on something, I realized later that I was just over-complicating it. As the game will tell you: If you get stuck on a puzzle, leave it for later and go do another one; the one you thought was impossible might seem trivial the next day. There are things you need to finish to unlock new "worlds" and new game mechanics, but you always have a bunch of puzzles that you can do in any order.

183609256.review:
Clearly plenty of people find this a satisfying puzzle game and there are indeed many puzzles of increasing complexity. However, somehow this game didn't quite "click" with me despite being a puzzle lover and each of the world themes appealing to my own specific interests.

I think ultimately I just found the puzzles a bit too repetitive and the overall story not as engaging as, for example, Portal. The story telling is subtle, which I actually also usually enjoy but although the topics were compelling, somehow it didn't really keep my attention as much here. I found the final "puzzle" or series of puzzles right before the ending to be the most interesting because it felt the most different despite using the same mechanics.

Maybe to avoid the same feeling it would be a good idea to spread it out over weeks or months instead of trying to continuously play and complete it if you think you might be interested but might have the same reaction.

What I can say is, this game did engage my brain, I enjoyed the puzzles most periodically when they felt fresh, and the ending was great.

I did also find I enjoyed Road to Gehenna much more, though the puzzles still felt repetitive since I played it right after the main game (well, within days)
